Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM1001 - International Indigenous Health","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online


This course aims to develop student’s understanding of core concepts in the health and well-being of Indigenous peoples worldwide, with particular focus on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in Australia and Indigenous peoples in United States (or the Americas more broadly). The course highlights the differences in distribution of disease and health disparities between Indigenous and non-Indigenous peoples and develops an understanding of underlying interrelated physical, psycho-social, cultural and other determinants of Indigenous peoples’ health. Students will be provided with examples of evidence-based research and health practice to learn about the ways in which Indigenous health and well-being can be supported.


 


 


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1924b240db357c90be4672f5f396195e","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students must make a weekly contribution to online discussion board forums focusing on key issues/readings for the week. Each post is to be approximately 100 - 150 words.  Students are required to demonstrate understandoing of concepts, readings and key issues in response to weekly discussion forum questions posed.  Students will be assessed on the quality and consistency of their interaction online and demonstration of engaging with the course resources and each other online.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"1124b240db357c90be4672f5f396195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1124b240db357c90be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1124b240db357c90be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1124b240db357c90be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1924b240db357c90be4672f5f396195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1924b240db357c90be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1924b240db357c90be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"1924b240db357c90be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d24b240db357c90be4672f5f396197d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Wiki page on a topical health issue in Indigenous communities","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

In groups, students prepare a group Wiki page on a specific health issue affecting Indigenous peoples (options provided). In the webpage, they should define the health problem, explain why it is of indigenous health importance, describe key risk factors, analyse the social and psychological consequences of this issue on Indigenous families and communities; and discuss an example of a program that addresses this health issue using supporting evidence.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1124b240db357c90be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1124b240db357c90be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1124b240db357c90be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1924b240db357c90be4672f5f396195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1924b240db357c90be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a124b240db357c90be4672f5f3961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Investigative Report on Improving Indigenous Health","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

Students are to prepare a report that investigates a significant health issue for a specific group of Indigenous people, and outline one or more public health responses that have been used to address the health issue.

Students need to consider:

- Contextual information about the group of Indigenous people chosen

- A summary of key measures that demonstrate the significance of impacts of the selected health issue on Indigenous health and wellbeing

-The historical, social and other determinants of health, including how they relate to the chosen health issue

- A description of one or more areas of public health action, that could include policies or strategies, advocacy activities or programs to address the issue.

Length: 1500-2000 words

Students are required to complete weekly blog entries.  Weeks 1-5 Are Part 1 and worth 10% and Weeks 6-10 are Part 2 and worth 10%. (20% total).  The Reflective blog provides an individual space where each student can reflect and articulate their own understandings, assumptions and developing understandings on International Indigenous Health.   It is expected students will write approximately 250 words in their blog each week.

contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online

This course aims to develop student’s understanding of core concepts in the health and well-being of Indigenous peoples worldwide, with particular focus on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in Australia and Indigenous peoples in United States (or the Americas more broadly). The course highlights the differences in distribution of disease and health disparities between Indigenous and non-Indigenous peoples and develops an understanding of underlying interrelated physical, psycho-social, cultural and other determinants of Indigenous peoples’ health. Students will be provided with examples of evidence-based research and health practice to learn about the ways in which Indigenous health and well-being can be supported.
contentlets.title: International Indigenous Health

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM2001 - Epidemiology","description":"

Epidemiology is a foundation discipline in public health. It is the study of who, where, what, why, and how of illness and disability in human populations: who is affected and most susceptible, where is it occurring, what are the causes, why is it occurring, and how is it spreading? Once we know this information, we can use the data gathered to plan and evaluate the effectiveness of strategies to prevent illness and disability from occurring in the first instance or to manage the symptoms when it has already developed.


This course introduces students to epidemiological principles and methods such as basic tools for measuring illness and risk factors in the population, interpreting and assessing the quality of scientific health evidence by critiquing a range of study designs, and reporting on epidemiological research.  


This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online.

Epidemiology is a foundation discipline in public health. It is the study of who, where, what, why, and how of illness and disability in human populations: who is affected and most susceptible, where is it occurring, what are the causes, why is it occurring, and how is it spreading? Once we know this information, we can use the data gathered to plan and evaluate the effectiveness of strategies to prevent illness and disability from occurring in the first instance or to manage the symptoms when it has already developed.

This course introduces students to epidemiological principles and methods such as basic tools for measuring illness and risk factors in the population, interpreting and assessing the quality of scientific health evidence by critiquing a range of study designs, and reporting on epidemiological research.  

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM2002 - Biostatistics","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online


Biostatistics is an introductory course to statistical methods used in the healthcare field. This course introduces students to the quantitative methods that are the cornerstone of public health research and evidence-based public health policy and practice. Students will learn about the principles of statistical reasoning, underlying assumptions, and methods to analyze and interpret data.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3624f240db357c90be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3624f240db357c90be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3e24f240db357c90be4672f5f396197a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f24f240db357c90be4672f5f39619a1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Two quizzes consisting of 5-10 multiple choice and numeric questions each. The quizzes are designed to serve as a formative tool and assess students' understanding of course content covered in the preceding. Feedback will be provided through the issuing of model answers and written commentary.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3624f240db357c90be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3624f240db357c90be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3e24f240db357c90be4672f5f396197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e24f240db357c90be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4724f240db357c90be4672f5f39619a6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

A final exam will consist of multiple-choice, extended numeric and free-text response questions. It will cover the content covered across all 10 weeks of the course. Feedback will be through the distribution of model answers and written commentary.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3624f240db357c90be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3624f240db357c90be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3e24f240db357c90be4672f5f396197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e24f240db357c90be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8324f240db357c90be4672f5f396199c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Through interaction with a multi-part scenario, students will apply biostatistically and SPSS skills to generate meaningful results. Students will also need to consider contextual issues and how these may influence the role and the ability to generate robust statistical results. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM2003 - Health Promotion","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online


Health Promotion is a fundamental component of any approach to public health and population health, whether it be research, policy or practice. The World Health Organisation defines health promotion as ‘Health promotion is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and to improve, their health. It moves beyond a focus on individual behaviour towards a wide range of social and environmental interventions.” (http://www.who.int/topics/health_promotion/en/ ). This course provides an overview of health promotion including examination of the social determinants of health, health literacy and foundations in health promotion. During the course students will explore the role of health promotion in addressing a range of current global health issues and their relevance to the field of public health. Students will examine contemporary perspectives on health and health promotion contributions to public health and population health responses. The course enables students to gain an understanding of  how health can be defined from different perspectives, and develop core knowledge of health promotion including its foundation theories, principles and concepts,. The course will equip students with the capacity to engage in public health and population health through the essential health promotion skills and understandings.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6f243640db357c90be4672f5f3961936","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written assignment 1A: Critical Analysis of a Health Promotion Initiative addressing an international health concern","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This is the group component of the written assignment and includes two tasks. 

Taks 1 involves a  literature search and analysis of the health  problem in the country context assigned to the group. The findings are to be presented in a report which examines the magnitude of the problem in the assigned country, the imapct of the problem, disparities and equity concerns for the allocated country and the social determinants of the problem.  

Task 2 involves a literature search for examples of two health promotion initiatives and presenting the findings as a report that outlines the target population, aims and objectives of the initiative, and health promoting activities undertaken as part of this initiative.

Length: 1500 words, excluding bibliography    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6b243640db357c90be4672f5f3961946","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab243640db357c90be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a3243640db357c90be4672f5f3961986","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written assignment 1B: Critical Analysis of a Health Promotion Initiative addressing an international health concern","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Part 2 of the written assignment is an individual component. Students will need to choose one of the health promotion initiatives identified by their group members in part 1 and undertake a critical analysis of the initiative in terms of Ottawa Charter action areas, health promotion principles and behaviour change  model(s) that may underpin the initiative.  

Length: maximum 1500 words (excluding references)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM2005 - Principles of Prevention and Public Health Surveillance","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online


Disease surveillance and population health monitoring represents one of the most important tools for public health, for early disease detection and prevention, and the monitoring and evaluation. Early detection of and rapid response to a public health threat has huge potential to save lives and costs from preventing hospitalisations and deaths. This course provides an overview of different types of surveillance systems and the sources of data that are used by such systems to generate useful information to inform evidence-based public health action. Students learn to assess the challenges and limitations associated with different types of public health surveillance and develop the skills to examine the tools and approaches that can be used to improve their effectiveness. The course looks at principles of disease prevention more broadly.  Public health prevention measures are discussed including immunisation and screening, using case studies for both communicable and non-communicable diseases. The role of epidemiological and social factors is also considered.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"30347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d0","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3 x quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Thee multiple choice quizzes based on understanding and applying concepts taught in the course. Each quiz is worth 10% of a student's overall marks for this course.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"34347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"34347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"34347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"34347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3c347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3c347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3c347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b4347640db357c90be4672f5f39619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Building on a scenario, in small groups (to be assigned by the course convenor) students will develop and justify a plan of surveillance action in response to a public health issue. Students are expected to undertake research to profile the issue and identify context-specific risk factors for a specific setting, make recommendations of an appropriate surveillance strategy to meet the information needs of decision-makers responsible for responding to the issue, and outline the activities involved in implementation. Students will provide their report as a 15-20 minute presentation.

In a 1000-1500 word essay, students will critique a surveillance system (or aspect of a system) to identify its use in public health practice and discuss the pros and cons of the method. The essay is worth 35% of a student's overall marks for this course.

Building on a scenario, in small groups (to be assigned by the course convenor) students will develop and justify a plan of surveillance action in response to a public health issue. Students are expected to undertake research to profile the issue and identify context-specific risk factors for a specific setting, make recommendations of an appropriate surveillance strategy to meet the information needs of decision-makers responsible for responding to the issue, and outline the activities involved in implementation. Students will provide their report as a 15-20 minute presentation.

contentlets.keywords: surveillance,prevention,public health surveillance systems,population health monitoring,immunisation,screening,preventive medicine,disease prevention,population health,public health
contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online

Disease surveillance and population health monitoring represents one of the most important tools for public health, for early disease detection and prevention, and the monitoring and evaluation. Early detection of and rapid response to a public health threat has huge potential to save lives and costs from preventing hospitalisations and deaths. This course provides an overview of different types of surveillance systems and the sources of data that are used by such systems to generate useful information to inform evidence-based public health action. Students learn to assess the challenges and limitations associated with different types of public health surveillance and develop the skills to examine the tools and approaches that can be used to improve their effectiveness. The course looks at principles of disease prevention more broadly.  Public health prevention measures are discussed including immunisation and screening, using case studies for both communicable and non-communicable diseases. The role of epidemiological and social factors is also considered.
contentlets.title: Principles of Prevention and Public Health Surveillance

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM2006 - Public Health Policy and Programs","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online


The overall aim of this course is to enable students to develop their understanding of both public health policy and programs as a part of public health practice.  Students will learn about the concept and role of policy and the key concepts, models and approaches to designing and evaluating public health programs. Case studies from multiple countries and contexts will be used as teaching material.

Student groups will need to include a justification for their program design plan.  Each group will be given a discussion board in which to formulate their plan. Further information will be provided on task allocation.

Length: Maximum 1200 words (excluding references)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM2007 - Health Leadership","description":"

This course is offered in two modes:  either face to face (on campus) and fully online


The course aims to develop students understanding of different approaches to leading and managing at different levels in health services in local and international contexts to improve individual, community and population level outcomes.  Students will be introduced to the common and overlapping skills and features of effective health leadership within public health agency settings requiring coordinated system-wide action through to health care management in more clinically focused patient delivery settings. Topics include management and leadership theories and models; systems perspectives and strategic thinking; influence, power and leading change; managing interprofessional teams and motivating staff; conflict management and improving health worker performance.

This course is offered in two modes:  either face to face (on campus) and fully online

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM2009 - Evaluating Chronic Disease Programs","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online.


As global populations grow, age and transition away from traditional ways of life, the causes of ill health and death are also changing. Chronic diseases such as heart disease, diabetes and cancer are now the largest causes of death and disability in nearly all countries today. Therefore, it has become vitally important to ensure that health programs to address chronic diseases are effective at improving and protecting the health of the population so that precious resources and effort is not wasted. Monitoring and evaluation of chronic disease health programs enables us to learn about how we can make improvements in order to improve people's health.


Successful completion of this course will provide students with foundational skills in program evaluation. Students will learn how to plan an evaluation strategy through using a series of chronic disease case studies representing a range of population settings. These case studies have been selected as they represent the main disease burdens currently afflicting global populations.

Each week, a question and answer discussion forum will be set up. A question relating to that week's learning material will be posted by the convenor. Students are expected to respond to the question and also post at least one additional post responding to another student's answer.

Each weekly discussion forum participation is worth 2% (10 x 2% = 20% total).

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM3001 - Ethics in Public Health","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online


This course provides an overview of ethical considerations and issues pertinent to public health and healthcare. Students will examine ethical theories and principles, and key legal concepts, and their application to healthcare and public health contexts.The course enables students to identify and analyse the ethical challenges of balancing the interests of individuals and communities within a healthcare context which is costly, complex and increasingly globalised. While the focus is on public health ethics which includes health policy and promotion, clinical and research ethics will also be examined as integral components of contemporary, cutting-edge healthcare service and delivery.

Multiple choice or short-answer questions on key legal and ethical concepts based on the lecture content and readings in Week 1-5 topics

Students identify health benefits and/or harms being addressed by a particular policy and analyse and evaluate the ethical framework underpinning it.

Length: 800 words

All learning outcomes assessed

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e634f640db357c90be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e634f640db357c90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e634f640db357c90be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ee34f640db357c90be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"ee34f640db357c90be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ee34f640db357c90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f634f640db357c90be4672f5f3961929","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Assignment: Ethical analysis of a public health issue","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online

This course provides an overview of ethical considerations and issues pertinent to public health and healthcare. Students will examine ethical theories and principles, and key legal concepts, and their application to healthcare and public health contexts.The course enables students to identify and analyse the ethical challenges of balancing the interests of individuals and communities within a healthcare context which is costly, complex and increasingly globalised. While the focus is on public health ethics which includes health policy and promotion, clinical and research ethics will also be examined as integral components of contemporary, cutting-edge healthcare service and delivery.
contentlets.title: Ethics in Public Health

real-world experience in preparation for a future career. Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM3003 - Public Health Capstone","description":"

This course provides students with an opportunity to bring together learning developed during their undergraduate program and to apply and further develop public health knowledge and skills through a research project, internship or public health study tour.


A pre-capstone preparatory phase will allow students to level expectations and develop a capstone proposal to guide their work during the course. Students will choose between a research project, internship placement or public health study tour based on interest, career aspirations and feasibility.


The capstone experience will be scaffolded by the proposal and support from the course convenor and research or workplace supervisor. The chosen experience will support the student’s public health interests and career aspirations, and a structured daily activity log and reflective journal (assessment task 2) will allow the student to relate their capstone to broader learning in the undergraduate program and their emerging position as a public health professional.


Students will complete the capstone by demonstrating their learning through a capstone report and presentation. These will include a summary of literature, reflection and progress against the proposal, together with an original piece of work consisting of either a research report, policy analysis, program evaluation, or written program plan.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1734f640db357c90be4672f5f39619ed","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Capstone background and proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are to conduct a scoping literature review of the context, public health area, program or research approach to be encountered during their capstone experience.

They are to provide this, together with a proposal for the capstone experience using the template provided through moodle.

The student’s capstone proposal will include:

  • A statement of aims related to professional development, the aims of the research project or internship or study tour and how these relate to public health interests and/ or career aspirations.
  • A timeline for completion; and
  • An account of any other resources or supports needed.

A draft of the scoping literature review and proposal is to be submitted in week 3 for early feedback.

The proposal is a work in progress and will be altered or affirmed in consultation with the student’s workplace, research or tour supervisor during phase 2 of the capstone course. A final version of the agreed upon capstone proposal will be submitted in week 5.

 

Word length: Scoping literature review 500 words.

Capstone proposal- no word limit/ template based.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1334f640db357c90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b34f640db357c90be4672f5f39619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1b34f640db357c90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f34f640db357c90be4672f5f39619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Supervisor evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment Description

The student’s workplace, study tour or research supervisor will provide an evaluation of the student’s professionalism, engagement with the work, initiative, and communication skills.

Each criterion will be scored out of 5 and supervisors will also provide a statement of feedback for each student.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9734f640db357c90be4672f5f39619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are to maintain a daily log and reflective journal of their experience through the capstone course. This should include:

  • an account of dates and hours worked
  • activities, accomplishments and any issues of note
  • reflection on professional and personal development through the capstone experience

At the end of the capstone experience, students are to revisit their reflective journal entries and provide a summary report of their entries.

This summary should include:

  • a critical appraisal and self-evaluation based on experiences throughout the course
  • evidence of growth in understanding and/or professional development
  • an evaluation of the success of the chosen capstone against aims detailed in the capstone proposal
  • perceived implications of their capstone experience for future career goals and area/s of public health practice.

Word length: 1000 words

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1334f640db357c90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1334f640db357c90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b34f640db357c90be4672f5f39619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1b34f640db357c90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"df34f640db357c90be4672f5f39619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Capstone Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"45","description":"

Students are to apply knowledge, skills and experience developed during the Capstone to create one of the following:

  • Research Report: Students who have chosen a research-based capstone are to write a report based on work conducted for their assigned research project. This will include objectives, methods, analysis, findings and a presentation of results, conclusions and recommendations.
  • Policy analysis: Students who have chosen a study tour or internship capstone may conduct a policy analysis. To do this, they must analyse the public health implications of a current or proposed policy. The analysis should include perspectives on economics and financing, need and demand, politics/ethics/law, or quality and effectiveness.
  • Evaluation of a program or intervention: Students who have chosen a study tour or internship capstone may evaluate an existing program or intervention. To do this, they will provide a description of the program or intervention, explain the purpose of the evaluation, describe the methods and procedures used to evaluate the program, identify the logistics of carrying out the evaluation, and present the results of the evaluation.
  • Written plan for a program or intervention to address a health issue exposed to during the capstone experience: Students who have chosen a study tour or internship capstone may create a plan for a new program. To do this, they will conduct a needs assessment, create a program mission, goals, and objectives, develop an intervention, describe how the program will be implemented, and explain how the program would be evaluated.
  • An output specific to work tasks: this is to be discussed with the convenor prior to beginning work on this assessment task, and clear parameters agreed upon by the student and course convenor.

 

Word length: 2000 words

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM3004 - Women's and Children's Health","description":"

In this course, students will explore important issues in women’s and children’s health globally and examine their contextual determinants. Through case studies and analysis, students will develop a deep understanding of the importance of addressing priority health concerns for these populations and examine public health approaches to the provision of health information and services for women and children in diverse contexts. A focus on the relationship between course content and application to practice is embedded, as are reflections on the Sustainable Development Goals and achieving Universal Health Coverage through equity and rights-based approaches.


The course takes a life-course approach to women’s and children’s health, moving from maternal and reproductive health, through newborn and child health and development, to adolescent health, and finally to priority women’s health issues.  Each week provides an overview of key health concerns relevant to that week’s topic area, and students conduct an exploration of the social and cultural determinants of these health issues, followed by a discussion of public health approaches to address these determinants and health outcomes. Social justice, equity and rights-based frameworks are applied to learning and discussion throughout the course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bb343a40db357c90be4672f5f396194f","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are required to write an essay addressing a specific children’s health problem or issue in a selected low/middle-income country or population.

The major essay should include:

1. A brief introduction to the selected country or population;

2. A clear description of the health problem or issue addressing why it is of public health significance in the selected population (include epidemiological data)

3. A list of current programs and/or policies addressing the issue and a detailed description of one of these.

4. A discussion of the remaining challenges

5. A rationale for one public health strategy to address one or more of the challenges

6. Key recommendations for policy makers, practitioners, and/or the public.

Length: 2000 words.

Students will receive written feedback.

Each student will be allocated to an online group consisting of a maximum of 8 members. Each group will have a discussion forum each week concerning a controversy or debate related to the weekly topic. Each student will be allocated a weekly topic in which they are expected to lead the discussion among their group for that week (be a moderator) and contribute an online post to all other discussion weeks (weeks 2 to 10). All online posts should be informed by the required readings for the given week to facilitate other group members’ participation. Each group member must contribute to at least 80% of the weekly discussion forums (7/9 online forums attended). Each student must provide a report log of all their posts and indicate their two best posts (excluding their allocated week). The log and best posts will be used to assess quality and consistency of student participation and contribution. The log and summary will be used to assess student moderation.

Online posts length: 250 words maximum.

In an online blog post, students are to outline and analyse an example of a community-based program or campaign addressing a current issue in women’s health in a selected country or population. The blog should include the following key information: background of the issue, evidence for the program’s or campaign’s effectiveness, key programme limitations or aspects of the issue that still need to be addressed, and the student’s recommended course of action. Students must also comment on a blog post written by one of their peers. Students will receive written feedback.

Length: 1500 words for the student’s own blog entries in total and 200 words maximum for comment on a peer’s blog (excluding references)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM3006 - Social Business for Public Health","description":"

The emerging field of social business comes against the backdrop of unleashing human ingenuity in which the market-driven approach for solving social problem (s) in health, education, environment etc stands as the primary objective. In this course, we will develop the skills and perspective that enable you to identify and understand a social problem, to generate creative ideas to address it, and to build a realistic social business plan.


The focus in the class shifts from the theoretical understanding of social business to the practical approach of planning, organising, leading and monitoring a social business. You will explore case studies, scenerious and real-time experiences from a largest Global academic and professional network of social business (i.e. Noble Laureate Professor Yunus Social business in 16 countries, 31 universities, 12 academic programs) and meet successful social business entrepreneurs to move your social business plan to market.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e0443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f3","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Online discussion is the tool through which students interact with each other about a course topic to gain further understanding from the cohort. As a multidisciplinary module, the course expects students from diversified backgrounds to elaborate a common notion of interest. From Weeks 2 to Week 10, students will participate in a weekly online discussion forum in small groups on Moodle (see in each weekly section for the week’s discussion forum).  Students will be randomly allocated to an online discussion group at the end of Week 1.   

\n

Each week, students will discuss a topic, with their group online.  Students must contribute to at least THREE of these weekly discussion forums – students can contribute to more weekly discussion forums, if you wish. Students will be assessed on how meaningfully they have contributed to their discussion group across the semester. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"64443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"38447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Social business plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

This exercise aims to prepare students to construct a social business plan from idea to actionable strategy that can solve a healthcare problem. Throughout the course, students will be exposed to various components of social business plan that can make the plan submission ready. Students are expected to work individually and elaborate their innovative solution regarding healthcare problems into an implementable social business plan containing the major apparatus discussed in the course. Students are required to submit a social business plan essay (2000 words) via Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"64443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"64443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6c443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6c443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e8443a40db357c90be4672f5f39619fb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Digital Pitch presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Digital Pitch presentation aims to train students to explain the problem to be solved. Each student needs to work with a healthcare problem that can be solved using social business tool. Student will prepare a short recorded or filmed presentation on what is the healthcare problem they are going to address in their social business plan via a smart phone or webcam. A 10 minutes video pitch presentation filmed on a smart phone or webcam will be submitted via Moodle.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM3007 - Applied Public Health Practice","description":"

In this course, students will work through four modules designed to consolidate knowledge and skills of public health and professional practice, to provoke self-reflection on attributes and capabilities, and to encourage forward thinking to career and study opportunities after completion of their undergraduate degree. Each module will run for two weeks from week 2, with an introductory week planned for week 1 and a review and consolidation week in week 10.


Module one, Positioning Yourself in Public Health requires students to use self-assessment tools to identify public health capabilities and career interests and aspirations. The second module Professional Practice and Career Development in Public Health provides students with the opportunity to engage with professional practice in public health, career development opportunities, and transferrable skills for future work. In the third module, Applied Public Health Research, students will be supported to consolidate and further extend applied research skills for public health, including in research design, research ethics, collaborative and inclusive research approaches, and research translation. The final module focuses on Communication for Public Health and will enable students to develop and apply skills in public health advocacy, the use of new media and technologies in public health promotion, and strategies for developing health information, education and communication outputs.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"05447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961960","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Applied Public Health Practice product and report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Applied Public Health Practice product and report 50%

Assessment Description:

Students are required to synthesise knowledge and skills developed during their undergraduate program, including within the Applied Public Health Practice course, and present these understandings through the development of a public health product and accompanying report.

A set of contemporary public health issues will be provided for students to choose between as a basis for the task.

In addition to requiring students to consider a significant public health challenge, this assessment is designed to allow students to follow intellectual and professional curiosities identified and articulated during the course. Two options are provided to students to facilitate this and students will be provided with an appropriate report template for each:

Option 1: Develop and present a public health advocacy product

Students will select from a set of public health issues of concern and undertake the following steps toward their assessment. Each step is identified within the report template:

  • Undertake a literature review of key peer reviewed and grey literature (approximately 10 documents) and present findings in spreadsheet or table form organised as appropriate by journal, authors, research question, method, findings, conclusions and limitations. This table will be included as an annex to the report.
  • Use findings from the literature review to compile an introduction and background and include these in the report.
  • Work through a scaffolded advocacy tool (included in the report template) and use the background literature review to:
  • Develop an advocacy goal framework (including identifying the problem and the desired change and stating the advocacy goal, objectives and indicators);
  • Identify and justify the target of advocacy efforts;
  • Select and build an appropriate advocacy approach and argument based on the literature review and target audience;
  • Define an ‘advocacy ask’; and
  • Produce an advocacy product (such as a policy briefing paper; an infographic to be shared through social media; a community radio announcement; an information, education, communication product; a targeted blog post; or other- in consultation with the course convenor) that aligns with the goal, target audience, and advocacy message. 
  • Provide a reflection on the process of producing an advocacy product and discuss how this aligns with public health studies and identified professional interests and career aspiration.
  • Provide an appropriate summary and conclusion to the advocacy task in relation to the public health issue.
  • Present the advocacy product in an appropriate form (video or audio recorded; graphic presentation; other) in addition to the completed report template.

 

Option 2: Research proposal and ethics application

Students will select from a set of public health issues of concern and undertake the following steps toward their assessment. Each step is identified within the report template:

  • Undertake a literature review of key peer reviewed and grey literature (approximately 10 documents) and present findings in spreadsheet or table form organised as appropriate by journal, authors, research question, method, findings, conclusions and limitations. This table will be included as an annex to the report.
  • Use findings from the literature review to compile an introduction and background to the intended research project and include these in the report.
  • Complete a template using the literature review and knowledge of applied public health research to formulate a research proposal and complete a simplified ethics application, including:
  • Research project title;
  • Research hypothesis/ goals/ objectives;
  • Research design (including methodology, research questions, proposed methods, sampling and recruitment, data analysis, data storage, privacy and confidentiality, and proposed dissemination of results);
  • Intended outcome of the research; and
  • Significance of the research.
  • Provide a reflection on the process of producing a research proposal and ethics application and discuss how this aligns with their public health studies and identified professional interests and career aspiration.
  • Provide an appropriate summary and conclusion to the research proposal and ethics application task in relation to the public health issue.
  • Present the research proposal and ethics application within the research report template.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"05447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0d447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0d447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"09447a40db357c90be4672f5f396196d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-assessment and learning contract","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are to complete the self-assessment workbook and incorporate a summary of findings from this exercise into a learning contract, designed to enable strategic goal setting, self-directed learning, and self-management during the Applied Public Health Practice course.

A learning contract template will be provided to students and will consist of the following components:

  • Self-reflection on current capabilities (skills, knowledge, experience, professional and transferrable skills), interests, and aspirations as a summary of self-assessment workbook;
  • Goals for the Applied Public Health Practice course in relation to current capabilities, interests and aspirations;
  • Activities to be completed during the Applied Public Health Practice course to meet goals;
  • Strategies and resources required to meet goals; and
  • Statement of evidence of achieving goals, and agreement for feedback and evaluation as goals completed. 

 

Students will submit a draft of their learning contract for early feedback and are able to revisit and update the document throughout the course before a final submission in week 10.

Length: Not specified- template based task.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"05447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0d447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0d447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c1447a40db357c90be4672f5f3961964","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Portfolio or profile development","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will collate and synthesise evidence for the knowledge, skills and attributes they have developed during their undergraduate program.

This will be presented against graduate capabilities using:

  • Option a: an online portfolio (such as Adobe Portfolio, Wix.com or other)
  • Option b: LinkedIn profile
  • Option c: a static option such as Microsoft Word or PDF

Students should consider the graduate capabilities and revisit their coursework during the undergraduate program, selecting examples of work that demonstrate their achievements or learning. These may include examples of written assessments, contribution to discussion boards, recorded work or any other part of the program that provides evidence of learning and development.

Students will provide a link to their e-portfolio or LinkedIn profile, or a copy of their static document.

contentlets.description:
In this course, students will work through four modules designed to consolidate knowledge and skills of public health and professional practice, to provoke self-reflection on attributes and capabilities, and to encourage forward thinking to career and study opportunities after completion of their undergraduate degree. Each module will run for two weeks from week 2, with an introductory week planned for week 1 and a review and consolidation week in week 10.

Module one, Positioning Yourself in Public Health requires students to use self-assessment tools to identify public health capabilities and career interests and aspirations. The second module Professional Practice and Career Development in Public Health provides students with the opportunity to engage with professional practice in public health, career development opportunities, and transferrable skills for future work. In the third module, Applied Public Health Research, students will be supported to consolidate and further extend applied research skills for public health, including in research design, research ethics, collaborative and inclusive research approaches, and research translation. The final module focuses on Communication for Public Health and will enable students to develop and apply skills in public health advocacy, the use of new media and technologies in public health promotion, and strategies for developing health information, education and communication outputs.
contentlets.title: Applied Public Health Practice

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM3008 - Physical Activity and Nutrition Advocacy and Communication","description":"

This course is offered in two modes:  either face to face (on campus) and fully online.


Modern public health advocacy is about working to change the physical and policy environment to encourage and better support populations to start and maintain healthy behaviours. To do this successfully, specific skill sets are needed: an ability to synthesize evidence and communicate this clearly to a wide range of diverse audiences, being able to work effectively in multi-disciplinary teams across sectors, and to engage effectively with communities.


In this course, students will learn how to develop a simple public health advocacy plan. As part of this, students will build their skills in communicating and engaging with decision-makers and local communities in order to drive public health actions. Physical activity and nutrition case studies will be used to help students practice these skills. These case studies have been selected as they are currently the main risk factors for poor health globally.

The assessment task is due one week after the end of Week 10 and feedback will be returned within 10 working days.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM4013 - Influencing Health Beliefs and Health Behaviours","description":"

It is the business of health promotion and all health care practitioners to influence the status quo towards promoting health. This course provides an overview of social aspects of health and foundations in health promotion. The course will enable you to examine contemporary social and cultural perspectives on health, healthcare and on people's everyday lived experience of health & illness. The course commences with analysis of theories, principles and strategies of influence for change, focussing on the individual. The course progresses to exploring the role of health promotion in addressing a range of contemporary public health problems at the community and national level. The course will include an examination of the role of sport in health promotion.

This course provides an overview of social aspects of health and foundations in health promotion. The course will enable you to examine contemporary social and cultural perspectives on health, healthcare and on people's everyday lived experience of health & illness. The course commences with analysis of theories, principles and strategies of influence for change, focussing on the individual. The course progresses to exploring the role of health promotion in addressing a range of contemporary public health problems at the community and national level. The course will include an examination of the role of sport in health promotion.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9010 - Community Development","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.


This course explores the meaning and conceptual frameworks of community development as an approach to improving the health of individuals and the broader community in both the local and international context. The material covered facilitates exploration of the fundamental components of community development, such as needs assessment, empowerment, and evaluation. Local and international case examples are used to explore theories and models in practice and to highlight and reflect on the issues and dilemmas faced in community development work across a range of settings. This course is useful for community workers, researchers, policy officers/managers, health service administrators/managers, educators or clinicians. For those with field experience, this course will provide a strong theoretical basis and will introduce some new practice tools. For those with little or no field experience, it provides a good mix of theories, models, practical examples and tools to introduce this exciting approach to improving health.

contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.

This course explores the meaning and conceptual frameworks of community development as an approach to improving the health of individuals and the broader community in both the local and international context. The material covered facilitates exploration of the fundamental components of community development, such as needs assessment, empowerment, and evaluation. Local and international case examples are used to explore theories and models in practice and to highlight and reflect on the issues and dilemmas faced in community development work across a range of settings. This course is useful for community workers, researchers, policy officers/managers, health service administrators/managers, educators or clinicians. For those with field experience, this course will provide a strong theoretical basis and will introduce some new practice tools. For those with little or no field experience, it provides a good mix of theories, models, practical examples and tools to introduce this exciting approach to improving health.
contentlets.title: Community Development

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9012 - Health Promotion and Social Perspectives of Health","description":"

This course provides an overview of social aspects of health and foundations in health promotion. The course will enable students to examine contemporary social and cultural perspectives on health, healthcare and on people's everyday lived experience of health & illness, and explore the role of health promotion in addressing a range of contemporary public health problems. Current global health issues and their relevance to health promotion and the field of public health are examined through analysis and application of best practice principles including assessment for effectiveness. The course moves students beyond the traditional silo approaches to health promotion that address risk factors and disease models. It focuses on social determinants and a multi-sectoral approach to promoting health through research, practice, policy and advocacy.Please note that Exercise Physiology students can only do this course in Stage 4.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9041 - Foundations in Public Health and Health Care Systems","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.


This course will introduce students to the public health and health care systems. Topics include: the history of public health, core functions of public health; surveillance and measurement of population health; principles of communicable and non-communicable disease control; social determinants of health; indigenous health; public health advocacy and evidence based public health; and an introduction to the Australian and other major health care systems.

Critical analysis of one disease or issue in the history of public health (prior to 1900). Students are expected to critically analyse the understanding of, and response to their selected disease or issue and are expected to produce evidence from the literature to support their assertions.

Word limit: 1000 words

Critically assessment of the literature. Students are expected to select one of three journal articles and scientifically critique the paper. Word limit: 1000 words

Students select one public health activity provided (e.g. measurement of the health of populations, health promotion, or health policy) and discuss the application of the selected activity to one risk group (e.g. refugees, people living with HIV, the poorest of the poor) in their country of choice.

Students are expected to prepare an essay that discusses the application of the selected public health activity or approach to the selected group, demonstrates their understanding of the selected public health activity: techniques, aims, strengths and limitations and compares and contrasts the various ways that approach applies to the selected group. Students should highlight the public health principles and priorities, the way they have been applied and the health outcomes, in the country of focus and support their statements with relevant evidence.  

Word limit: 2500 words

contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.

This course will introduce students to the public health and health care systems. Topics include: the history of public health, core functions of public health; surveillance and measurement of population health; principles of communicable and non-communicable disease control; social determinants of health; indigenous health; public health advocacy and evidence based public health; and an introduction to the Australian and other major health care systems.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9050 - Immunisation Policy and Practice","description":"

This course is designed for those working in public health or related disciplines who have an interest in immunisation, and would like to broaden their knowledge and skills. This course will provide students with a comprehensive appreciation of vaccine-preventable disease epidemiology and national immunisation policies relevant to low, middle and high resourced countries and in the context of global immunisation goals.


The course encompasses diverse aspects from vaccine development and clinical trials, policy development, program implementation and evaluation, vaccine safety and public perceptions of risk. This course aims to provide graduates with knowledge and skills in the epidemiological principles and policy issues to contribute to the development, implementation and evaluation of immunisation programs. The course draws on internationally recognised experts with a breadth of experience, and has an emphasis on practical learning experiences using real case scenarios. PHCM9050 Immunisation Policy and Practice will consist of weekly lectures and tutorials.


It is important that students enrolling in the course have knowledge and experience in public health or a health-related area. Interested students, who are not enrolled in a Masters program offered by the School of Population Health will need to contact the course convenor, who will assess whether they have the appropriate background, before enrolling in PHCM9050 Immunisation Policy and Practice.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9082 - Advanced Health Economics and Financial Management","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.


This course builds on the topics covered in PHCM9441 Healthcare Economics and Financial Management. This course will cover health policy related issues from economic perspective including topics such as National Health Reform, Activity based Funding, workings of health insurance markets and how demand for health care is managed given limited supply of health care. In addition, more advanced topics in financial management such as capital budgeting and costing of health services will be introduced.

contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.

This course builds on the topics covered in PHCM9441 Healthcare Economics and Financial Management. This course will cover health policy related issues from economic perspective including topics such as National Health Reform, Activity based Funding, workings of health insurance markets and how demand for health care is managed given limited supply of health care. In addition, more advanced topics in financial management such as capital budgeting and costing of health services will be introduced.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9100 - Academic Practice","description":"

These are student based workshops designed to provide support in academic skills needed to successfully complete the assignments in postgraduate studies in the School. Students will be expected to bring reading and writing material that pertain to their studies in other courses.Each week, skills topics will be presented and they will be linked with the materials that students deal with in their other courses. Participants will engage in critical activities on materials used in their studies ie reviewing articles, assignments etc. There will be opportunity to discuss issues and field questions from colleagues to develop skills in defending a particular viewpoint or position.


All new International students must complete Academic Practice in their first term of study. The course is worth 0 units of credit. The course is not counted in your study load and there are no tuition fees to be paid. Any International students who would like to be exempt from the course should contact the Postgraduate Office in the first instance. All Local students are also invited to enrol in the course.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PHCM9103","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9103 - Independent Study","description":"

This course is available to students enrolled in the MPH, MGH, MHLM, MIDI or associated dual and extension postgraduate coursework programs, who achieve a WAM of 65 or above after completion of at least 18UoC of their program, including core courses. Students wishing to enrol in Independent studies must obtain permission from the Program Director.


The Independent Studies elective is an option for students to propose a 6UoC unit of in-depth study of a relevant public health, global health, health management or infectious diseases intelligence issue or topic that addresses specific learning outcomes not otherwise covered in core or elective courses taught by the School. Public health and health management are broad disciplines and this elective is offered to meet the diverse learning needs of our students.


The overall learning experience for students is independent study with individual supervision by an academic supervisor. Independent Studies are student-led proposals with learning outcomes, proposed study plans and assessments negotiated with academic supervisors. Students must provide a rationale for why they wish to undertake the 6UoC Independent Studies elective. Students must also identify how the learning outcomes for the Independent Studies will contribute to the broader learning outcomes of their program. Candidates are expected to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge and skills gained in their program during their Independent Studies.


All proposals to undertake research should be submitted via the 6/12/18UoC Research Project elective options, not the Independent Studies elective.


Further Information: Independent Studies - Application Guidelines.

contentlets.description:
This course is available to students enrolled in the MPH, MGH, MHLM, MIDI or associated dual and extension postgraduate coursework programs, who achieve a WAM of 65 or above after completion of at least 18UoC of their program, including core courses. Students wishing to enrol in Independent studies must obtain permission from the Program Director.

The Independent Studies elective is an option for students to propose a 6UoC unit of in-depth study of a relevant public health, global health, health management or infectious diseases intelligence issue or topic that addresses specific learning outcomes not otherwise covered in core or elective courses taught by the School. Public health and health management are broad disciplines and this elective is offered to meet the diverse learning needs of our students.

The overall learning experience for students is independent study with individual supervision by an academic supervisor. Independent Studies are student-led proposals with learning outcomes, proposed study plans and assessments negotiated with academic supervisors. Students must provide a rationale for why they wish to undertake the 6UoC Independent Studies elective. Students must also identify how the learning outcomes for the Independent Studies will contribute to the broader learning outcomes of their program. Candidates are expected to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge and skills gained in their program during their Independent Studies.

All proposals to undertake research should be submitted via the 6/12/18UoC Research Project elective options, not the Independent Studies elective.

Further Information: Independent Studies - Application Guidelines.

This course covers techniques and tools used in the design and evaluation of health programs and projects. Program planning, needs assessment, program logic and logic models and intervention design will be covered in project/program design with an emphasis on public health interventions. Approaches to program evaluation will be used to teach techniques for program monitoring and evaluation. This includes use of Log Frames for process and impact evaluation. Case studies from both developed and developing countries will be used as teaching material.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHCM9120 - Qualitative Research Methods","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.


Introduces a range of qualitative research methods and techniques, including participant observation, in-depth interviews and focus groups and their application to public health and health promotion. The course further aims to provide students with introductory skills for developing, conducting, documenting and analysing interviews as a method and understanding how people interpret health and illness and the contexts in which they occur. Recommended as an introduction to this approach for  students including those wishing to undertake research projects using qualitative methods.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"04367a0cdb357c90be4672f5f39619e1","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Paper Critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Length: 1200 words maximum (excluding reference list).

Description:

You are to choose one paper from the two provided below to critique for this assignment.

1) Newman, Christy E., Gray, Rebecca, Brener, Loren, Jackson, L., Clair BA, Dillon, Anthony, Saunders, Veronica EN, Johnson, Priscilla & Treloar, Carla (2017) “I Had a Little Bit of a Bloke Meltdown…But the Next Day, I Was Up”: Understanding Cancer Experiences Among Aboriginal Men, Cancer Nursing, volume 40(3), p E1-E8. https://er1.library.unsw.edu.au/er/cgi-bin/eraccess.cgi?url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1097/NCC.0000000000000399

2) Yvonne Laird, Samantha Fawkner & Ailsa Niven (2018) A grounded theory of how social support influences physical activity in adolescent girls, International Journal of Qualitative Studies on Health and Well-being, 13:1, 1435099, DOI: 10.1080/17482631.2018.1435099.  https://er1.library.unsw.edu.au/er/cgi-bin/eraccess.cgi?url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/17482631.2018.1435099

Your critique is to be around the concepts of rigour covered in the course and the analysis presented and argued in the paper. You are not being asked to critique the study design as such, as you may have done already in other courses. The focus is more on the analysis, rigour and ethics of the study and its findings. Please not some questions may not be as relevant to the chosen paper as others. You do not need to answer every question, but choose at least three you feel comfortable addressing using the literature to support your arguments.

Start by giving a brief (250 words maximum) summary of the paper chosen. Then briefly introduce the critique, identifying the issues you will cover in your work. Then address three of the questions below (or ones you have devised). Finally, write a brief conclusion to your critique. You may use sub-headers if this is helpful in structuring your assignment. Make sure the referencing is done consistently in the APA style.

Below are some examples of questions you could ask of the paper and the analysis. You don't have to address all the questions and you could pose other questions you think are relevant:

  • How have the researchers addressed rigour and ethics in study design and methods?
  • Is the approach to analysis and the techniques used well described?
  • Is there theory development in the form of a step-by-step account of how theoretical insights are built up and/or are there novel claims?
  • Are claims/theory development grounded in actual data?
  • Is there rich description? Is there attention given to negative cases?
  • Are findings transferable (note, not "reproducible" or "statistically generalisable")?
  • Is the analysis reflexive (i.e., do the researchers take account of the potential impact of research(er) on setting/participants)?

Remember, to critique something does not necessarily mean to find flaws in it, engaging critically with a paper means reflecting on the paper's strengths and weaknesses.

The UNSW Learning Centre has some good guidelines on writing critical reviews: https://students.unsw.edu.au/writing-critical-review. In this course we are asking for a specific focus (above) so, after referring to the Learning Centre to get a general idea, be guided by what we are asking for in this assignment. Critique or critical comment is about taking a position in relation to someone else's work and so it includes your own ideas about the paper -- this must be an argued position, not just an unsupported opinion or an assertion about your feelings on reading the paper.
